Executive Summary
CENTAURI Technologies, LP

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies :  CENTAURI Technologies, LP produces variable specialty chemical products used in multiple industries.  One product is a specialty amine, which uses Methylamine as a raw material.  Another product is a high molecular weight polymer, which uses Propylene Oxide as a raw material.  These raw materials, in the amounts handled in our facility, are considered hazardous by the EPA.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  CENTAURI Technologies manages the safety of the regulated process by means of operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems designed to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel supplement the inherent safe design of the plant.

Our emergency response program is based upon OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and Hazardous Material unit so that appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to control accidental releases.

This document has been prepared in accordance with the EPA's Risk Management Plan regulation (40 CFR, Part 68).  The substance and process considered during the preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria established in the regulation.

2.	The stationary source and regulated substance handled :  The primary purpose of this facility is the production of specialty chemical products.  CENTAURI receives bulk Methylamine as a raw material and unload the material into pressurized liquid storage.  The methylamine is then fed continuously from storage into a reaction system where it is mixed with another reactive species to form the specialty amine product.  Excess methylamine is re

moved from the reaction system effluent by a distillation process and recycled back into the bulk liquid methylamine storage tank.  The maximum amount of this substance at this facility would be 32,000 pounds.

	CENTAURI receives bulk Propylene Oxide as a raw material and unloads the material into pressurized liquid storage.  The propylene oxide is then batch charged incrementally from storage into a reaction system where it is mixed with another reactive species to form the high molecular weight polymer product.  Excess propylene oxide is removed from the reaction system effluent by a distillation process and recycled back into the bulk liquid propylene oxide storage tank.  The maximum amount of this substance at this facility would be 20,000 pounds.

3.	The worst-case release scenario (WCS) : The worst case scenario, defined by the EPA, associated with Methylamine (flammable substance) at this facility is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) involving the maximum inventory of the methylamine storage tank.  A full vessel inventory of 32,000 pounds is assumed to be released and ignite, resulting in a VCE.  The maximum distance to the EPA defined endpoint of 1 psi overpressure does not reach receptors off-site (distance to endpoint 0.09 miles).  Although we have active controls directed at preventing such releases and controlling the consequences, no credit for active mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this WCS.

	The worst case scenario, defined by the EPA, associated with Propylene Oxide (toxic liquid) at this facility is a liquid release involving the maximum inventory of the Propylene Oxide storage tank.  A maximum vessel inventory of 20,000 pounds is assumed to be released and contained in the area containment sump.  The maximum distance to the EPA defined toxic endpoint of 0.59 mg/L does not reach receptors off-site (distance to endpoint < 0.1 miles).  Although we have active controls directed at preventing such releases and controlling th

e consequences, no credit for active mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this WCS.

4.	The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps :  The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Plan and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  This facility was designed and constructed to comply with applicable state and industry codes.

5.	Five year accident history :  This facility came on line in September of 2001.  In the last five years, there have been no accidents involving or accidental releases of methylamine or propylene oxide that resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6.	The emergency response program :  All facility employees have been trained to OSHA's HAZWOPER, First Responder Awareness Level in order to identify the need for an initiated response.  Retraining is conducted annually.

	The facility maintains a Release Prevention, Control and Countermeasure Plan that contains specific procedures for employees to take in the event of an emergency or accidental release.  This information also contains the names and numbers of responding outside agencies.  Emergency actions and response for flammable releases have been coordinated with the City of Pasadena Fire Department.  Annual updates to review these activities are completed with the responding agency.

7.	Planned changes to improve safety :  The facility resolves recommendations from PHAs and Incident Investigations, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operation procedures.
